abstract.text: A control that provides additional quantitative information specific to a menu item, such as the number of available updates.

inlineContent.text: You create a badge using an initializer or a predefined factory method, and then you assign it to the
For example, to display a badge with a count, use the
initalizer, passing in the value of

code: let menuItem = NSMenuItem(title: "Messages", action: nil, keyEquivalent: "")
// Add the item to the menu.
// Add the item to the menu.

inlineContent.text: To display a badge with a custom string, use the
initializer, passing in the string you want to display.

code: let menuItem = NSMenuItem(title: "Changes", action: nil, keyEquivalent: "")
// Set the badge to display "3 changes".
// Add the item to the menu.
// Set the badge to display "3 changes".
// Add the item to the menu.

inlineContent.text: To display a badge using a predefined
, use a factory method such as

code: // Add a new items style badge.
let newItemsItem = NSMenuItem(title: "New Items", action: nil, keyEquivalent: "")
let alertsItem = NSMenuItem(title: "Alerts", action: nil, keyEquivalent: "")
let updatesItem = NSMenuItem(title: "Updates", action: nil, keyEquivalent: "")
// Add a new items style badge.
NSMenuItem *newItemsItem = [[NSMenuItem alloc] initWithTitle:@"New Items" action:nil keyEquivalent:@""];
NSMenuItem *alertsItem = [[NSMenuItem alloc] initWithTitle:@"New Items" action:nil keyEquivalent:@""];

inlineContent.text: If you use one of the predefined badge types, the system localizes and pluralizes the string for you. If you create your own custom badge string, you need to localize and pluralize that string yourself. For more information on how to localize and pluralize text, see
The default value of this property is

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
An object that manages an app’s menus.
The optional methods implemented by delegates of
objects to manage menu display and handle some events.
A command item in an app menu.
A control that provides additional quantitative information specific to a menu item, such as the number of available updates.
Constants that define types of badges for display.
Creates an alert-style badge with an integer count and a predefined label that represents the number of alerts.
Creates a badge with a count and an empty string.
Creates a badge with the provided custom string.
The number of items the badge displays.
Creates a new item-style badge with an integer count and a predefined label that represents the number of new items.
The string representation of the badge as it would appear when
the badge is displayed.
The string representation of the badge when it displays.
The type of items the badge displays.
Creates an update-style badge with an integer count and a predefined label that represents the number of available updates.
Use a string catalog to translate text, handle plurals, and vary the text your app displays on specific devices.

doc://com.apple.documentation/documentat.title: Localizing and varying text with a string catalog

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can encode itself to an external representation.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type that can decode itself from an external representation.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.

media-4304515.alt: A menu containing five menu items with each menu item displaying a different style of badge. A NSMenuItem callout points to a menu item in the menu. A NSMenuItemBadge call out points to the badge that displays to the right of the menu item.
